comments.commentBody:
KJ : I get it and appreciate your point of view. There is a huge difference in the modern upbringing of the children and the good olden days. Those were the days of large families and as such there were plenty of children to play and interact with. I have no objection if a parent gets bored with a tiny tot but the parent shouldn't stop at that since it doesn't help matters improve.

Nowadays, mainly because of small or some times single parent families and also due to the fear factor and the government restrictions like those in America and also due to the fact that both parents have to work to meet certain affordability, the options for the outside exposure of the children has become very limited. As such parents have no choice but to engage their children in a way that can only help them to learn and speak faster.

So how come the Republican presidential candidates are still talking about "debasing the dollar". The dollar basically is allowed to float, which means it does not change drrastically from day-to-day. Germany plays this game very well with the EURO, in its exports, especially to the rest of Europe, the Euro is an undervalued Mark, but without the increaased cost of imports which would otherwise ensue.

I used DeCicco cavatappi instead of bucatina and added Ragu Chunky Garlic instead of canned chopped tomatoes with juice to the garlic and oil.  I also added pitted kalamata olives at the end and used shredded 4 cheese italian blend.  It was delicious and no one knew they were eating cauliflower!

and Elke

Hey Kiki- just between you and me: You changed your avatar. While you say you "prefer Alberta ", your avatar is the flag of British Columbia.....the province next door.... ...

There has been no change in Cuba since Obama's rapprochement began in December of 2014. The repression has gotten worse for dissidents. Would you ask a Holocaust survivor to forget the "bad blood" of the past? As with the victims of the Nazis, Castro's victims demand justice. Castro has executed 14,000 innocent Cubans without trial and 77,000 have drowned in the Straits of Florida while attempting to flee the genocidal regime. Today, half of Cuba's 12 million citizens have stated they would leave Cuba if they were permitted. All the tourism and commerce in the world will not change the sociopolitical or economic conditions of the average Cuban. This is a historical and political fact that Obama ignores. Freedom is the fount from which all progress and success has its genesis. Civil liberties and respect for human rights will always trump business interests.

NYT: Please do not delete and censor this comment. If you do, you are replicating the tactics of Castro's totalitarian regime. It is wrong and violates the individual's
right to free speech. I speak the truth.

Freedom for Cuba! Justice for the Cuban people!

I'm glad there are those who actually get to see the progress of change. They get to see actual change. They get to see people get freedom no matter how limited. Do I wish there was more? Yes I do. I wish that the fact that when people think of Cuba the don't think bad things like communism and what has happen in the past. I do wish that people will put all the bad blood between us and this little island in the past where it belongs. I do want the people of this island to know what full freedom is and what it feels like.

I love this so much. These people are doing what they absolutely love regardless of their age. People might say that the elderly have done their thing in life and the best years are behind them, but these people are running marathons and jumping hurdles and setting records. These people are ding things to make them feel like their young again and not like they are just waiting to die. This is how I think people of any age should be living , with not a care in the world doing things that get them smiling.
Of course no mention of women who are lesbian and have no desire for heterosexual sex.

I was amazed to see the 1985 photo of abandoned cars at West 112th Street & Amsterdam in front of St John the Devine. My wife and I moved to an apartment on that very block in 1988.  Though breaking into cars was still common, the atmosphere had already started to change for the better by then. We always drive there when we visit these days with the kids.  Thanks for posting this interesting photo collection and story (the statistics are remarkable).
That's the West Side Highway I remember.
I still remember my first trip to NYC, in the late 70's, riding in from LaGuardia seeing NY cops hiding in the wreckage of a trashed car's skeleton with their radar gun... Welcome to The Big Apple!
Those abandoned cars were a nice source of free parts back in the 60's and 70's.
Hard to believe even the 2156 number these days. Just dont see them at all, anymore.

The problem with your logic is that you automatically assume natural "femininity" is the narrow little box women have been shoved in for the benefit of men since the beginning of humans. If it were all so "natural", women wouldn't be able to succeed in the "male paradigm. But they're not. Men are just angry because women can do what they want now. Too bad. We don't have to settle anymore so men can either change, or get winnowed out. It's as simple as that.

What are you talking about? This article is about the Chinese society, not ours, and the men in that country aren't reviled because they aren't married; the women are. They're not calling the men "throwaways", just the women.

As far as men who aren't wealthy in this country, well, most men I know are at best middle class and 90+% of them have wives or girlfriends, so the whining about how greedy and materialistic women are about what men make just doesn't ring true in my 55 year world. I'm sure it happens, I just don't believe it happens to the extent that many men portray. Even if it did, I'll start caring a little more when women aren't passed over by men because they're looks and/or body type isn't HB8+.

Growing up in NY I definitely remember the abandoned cars!

However, I would encourage everyone to click the link to the Volvo ad and scroll to the top of the page. There is a great little story about 277 stolen rail cars in Illinois that links it to then deposed Bonnano crime family patriarch Joseph Bonnano. Great quick read of a bumbling railroad that claims the 277 car loss is just "a big mistake!". It's a good chuckle...
"devision"… department.

[[The building was a chop shop. Ironically, now it is an overpriced condo.]]

That's not "ironic."

It would be ironic if the location became the headquarters for the devision that looks for stolen cars.

I lived  on 95th and Second ave from 1981 until 1991 and there were always cars up on blocks , it just seemed normal back then. The only time anyone really noticed was when the cars burned and in the summer that use to happen with some frequency. Have not been back up there in years but have to assume the cars are all gone now.
Yes, I'll take burnt out cars over hipsters anyday!

If you had told me 30 years ago, as a child of a New England suburb, that I would one day be living down here in "New York City," my eyes would have grown wide in disbelief, and these photos illustrate why. I remember traveling down on day trips into the city, first I-91, then I-95 and the landscape grew steadily denser and harder. Then as we drove through the Bronx and seeing the abandoned buildings and the chopped up cars--it made me wonder about the souls who actually managed to live here. How did they normalize the decay?

I can't be nostalgic for any of this--I didn't live through it. It's a reminder, though, of how far the city has turned in the past generation. Wow!
The photo you're alluding to wasn't on FNC, but a local Fox affiliate.... you know.... one of those stations that shows The Simpson reruns over and over. Not the same.

Well part of it is that modern cars are too difficult to steal for the average thief. Really - only organized crime rings are sophisticated enough to steal cars. They are so computerized too that not even the average stripper can do it. In those days stealing a car was simple - and so was stripping them. Cars that are stolen now are more likely shipped overseas since here - cars are relatively "cheap".

That - and people are more vigilante. I don't know where the false nostalgia comes from. The city was "fun" - but it was a dump when I was growing up. Now if only we could do something about litter and street graffiti.

In my old Brooklyn neighborhood abandoned cars were frequently left in front of the abandoned church on my corner. This was before 311 so I'd call Sanitation and they'd eventually tag the car and tow it away. Another spot where many cars were abandoned was a desolate stretch of 21st Avenue where it passed through Washington Cemetery.

The few abandoned cars I've seen in my current neighborhood are reported online to 311. Mostly stolen cars dumped buy thieves. Cops today can run the VIN# from their patrol cars to see the status of the vehicle.

Abandoned cars without license plates can be reported at:
https://www1.nyc.gov/apps/311universalintake/form.htm?serviceName=DSNY+D...

Abandoned cars with license plates can be reported at:
https://www1.nyc.gov/apps/311universalintake/form.htm?serviceName=NYPD+A...

EK's attitude at the time seemed more focused on their competition with Polaroid, and a huge amount of research effort (literally millions) was thrown into this project -if only we'd had some people who had the vision to foresee developments (sorry for all the photographic puns!) in electronics which were just around the corner, and ironically which Kodak were assisting in with the work of Wagner/Stevens/Pitts/Padday in the UK. The writing was on the wall when EK lost out to Fuji for the sponsorship of the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, and amplified by the decisions made by the EK Management to devote itself to it's core products, ie silver halide technology, at about that time. As a former Kodak person, it saddens me to read this article, and to think what might have been - but who had the foresight to imagine what was about to happen with all of the parallel technologies of the time, apart from the likes of Steve Sasson?

Google maps. The last picture, 34 years later, the graffiti is painted over, the fire escape is still there, as are the crack in the wall beneath the window and that weird piece of metal attached to the wall to the right.
